channel.title: 纽约时报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Breaking News: New York City will require employees at yeshivas, Catholic schools and other private schools to be vaccinated against the coronavirus. The new directive is expected to affect roughly 930 schools and 56,000 employees, city officials said. https://t.co/77HWJFfBeD

A former Ohio sheriff’s deputy has been charged with murder in the death of Casey Goodson Jr. last year. Goodson, a 23-year-old Black man, was shot several times in the back during an operation that had nothing to do with him, according to an indictment. https://t.co/U5voTep3UQ

Germany announced new rules to prevent unvaccinated people from going to bars and restaurants, or shop anywhere but places like pharmacies or grocery stores to break a soaring fourth wave of Covid and prevent the spread of the Omicron variant. https://t.co/skOiu1CkZC

A Democratic pollster issued a warning to his party ahead of the 2022 elections after holding focus groups with Virginia voters.
"We’ve got a national branding problem that is probably deeper than a lot of people suspect." https://t.co/BVCC8owAmh

Two Georgia election workers who were falsely accused of manipulating ballots during the 2020 election are suing The Gateway Pundit, one of the nation’s leading sources of pro-Trump misinformation for defamation. https://t.co/2U1y5ka5IR

China’s censors have begun scrubbing references to Peng Shuai and the sexual assault allegations she made against a former vice premier from the internet. But her supporters are still finding ways to talk about her. https://t.co/zJScFxtmVL

Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, won a decisive victory in her long-running legal feud with The Mail on Sunday on Thursday, in her claim that the British tabloid violated her privacy by publishing a letter she sent to her estranged father. https://t.co/2JowRUJYjq
Breaking News: President Biden is expected to unveil a winter Covid plan today that includes insurance reimbursement for at-home tests and new travel protocols. https://t.co/z4nw6HSrEW

The first Israeli to test positive for the Omicron variant interacted with dozens of people. Only one has tested positive since.
The results have given some experts cautious hope that triple-vaccinated people may not be as vulnerable as was first feared. https://t.co/b1tSv6Ny63

The Supreme Court's six-member conservative majority appears divided about whether to overrule Roe v. Wade entirely. If they were to do so, at least 20 of the 50 U.S. states will immediately or in short order make almost all abortions unlawful. https://t.co/I5p3mVgXVX

During his 2018 confirmation hearing, Justice Brett Kavanaugh declared that he considered Roe to be settled law, winning him the crucial support of Senator Susan Collins. A reversal by him would be politically explosive, says @hillhulse.
Listen live: https://t.co/dPjpquzIgH

Breaking News: A 15-year-old boy was charged with terrorism and first-degree murder in connection with the Michigan school shooting that left at least four students dead on Tuesday. Officials are considering charges against his parents. https://t.co/qymSqjcQHf
Breaking News: President Biden will extend a mask mandate for travelers on airplanes, trains and buses, a person familiar with the decision said. https://t.co/Jx3Ccaf0ea
Marcus Lamb, a Christian broadcaster in Dallas who had been dismissive of Covid-19 vaccinations, died on Tuesday after contracting the coronavirus, his family said. https://t.co/lxwS1q6n4A

Justice Clarence Thomas asked if there's a constitutional right to abortion, saying it's not spelled out the way the Second Amendment is.
"It's liberty, your honor," Julie Rikelman, the litigation director at the Center for Reproductive Rights, replied.https://t.co/SfiUn06cz1 https://t.co/VBhFTUALjI

Alec Baldwin said in an upcoming television interview that he did not pull the trigger of the gun that fired a live round on the set of the film "Rust," killing the film’s cinematographer and wounding its director. https://t.co/tKSzUS9HCA

The Tucson Police Department moved to fire a police officer after he was captured on video fatally shooting a man in a wheelchair who was suspected of stealing a toolbox from a Walmart and flashing a knife. https://t.co/4DlQIPRzcc

The UN secretary general expressed strong criticism of the international response to the Omicron variant, saying that the rush to close borders has especially penalized African nations where the variant was first detected and vaccines were slow to arrive. https://t.co/Y1aMlbZ8US https://t.co/EGfmQbyHd6

Breaking News: The Supreme Court seems poised to uphold Mississippi's law, which bans abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy, after hearing arguments on Wednesday. But the court's conservative majority appeared split about overruling Roe v. Wade entirely. https://t.co/Cj9TYacIp6 https://t.co/v2JiwBPMg3

"I think this is every parent's worst nightmare," Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan said after a fatal shooting at Oxford High School on Tuesday. "No one should be afraid to go to school, work, a house of worship, or even their own home," she added. https://t.co/wfK8MUJSww

Breaking News: Gov. Charlie Baker of Massachusetts, a moderate Republican who defied Donald Trump during his two terms, said he would not seek re-election next year. He faced a Trump-backed primary challenge and a potentially difficult general election. https://t.co/kciT4EoQ3T

"I am required by the state of Mississippi to tell you that having an abortion will increase your risk of breast cancer," a doctor told patients on a typical morning at the last abortion clinic in the state. She added without hesitation: "It doesn't." https://t.co/yoJmkNIZK3

A 15-year-old student surrendered to the police after firing a semiautomatic handgun 15 to 20 times at Oxford High School in Oakland County, Michigan, the authorities said. At least three people — all believed to be students — are dead, officials said. https://t.co/zmtg8z6JzY

A federal appeals court on Tuesday restored California's prohibition on high-capacity magazines, a decision with national implications that could also lead to the reinstatement of a state ban on semiautomatic weapons. https://t.co/wsL7L7QCdL

Barbados became a republic and swore in its first president, Sandra Mason, during a ceremony on Tuesday that formally ended nearly 400 years of British rule. Attendees included the pop star Rihanna, who was declared a national hero. https://t.co/iAZemaafAd https://t.co/Kke38TDWN7

Barbados became a republic on Tuesday, cutting ties with Queen Elizabeth II and ending nearly 400 years of British rule. The island swore in its first president, Sandra Mason, at a ceremony attended by Prince Charles and Rihanna. https://t.co/7CbTbiVvTD
Breaking News: A federal judge blocked President Biden's nationwide vaccine mandate for health workers. The new rule was set to begin next week. https://t.co/XlRQyhgwoU

Breaking News: Chris Cuomo was indefinitely suspended by CNN on Tuesday after new details emerged about his efforts to assist his brother, former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, against a cascade of sexual harassment accusations. https://t.co/HCTCdaOa6k
Breaking News: Donald Trump tested positive for Covid days before facing Joe Biden in their first debate, and before he told the public, two ex-officials said. https://t.co/WR8gzY6eq9

Breaking News: Mark Meadows, Donald Trump’s former chief of staff, agreed to cooperate with the House panel investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, a stunning reversal for a crucial witness in the inquiry. https://t.co/w5ijOZqD0e

Breaking News: Stacey Abrams announced that she would run for governor of Georgia in 2022, aiming to unseat Gov. Brian Kemp in a rematch of the contentious 2018 election. https://t.co/DgWbCvihK0 https://t.co/J59ksFV6pE

Breaking News: The first U.S. case of the Omicron variant has been detected in California. Over 20 other nations now have cases of the Omicron variant, as questions about its impact remain. Track its spread here. https://t.co/o06X5GOLTj

Breaking News: The women’s professional tennis tour said it was immediately suspending all tournaments in China in response to Peng Shuai’s disappearance. Shuai said last month that she was sexually assaulted by a top member of the Chinese government. https://t.co/yFnvMKf2jW

Breaking News: Three people were killed in a shooting at Oxford High School in Michigan, north of Detroit, the authorities said. The dead were all believed to be students, officials said, and a 15-year-old student has been taken into custody. https://t.co/Xe3t4JTJWr

Greece will make Covid vaccines mandatory for people ages 60 or older, and those who fail to book a first shot by Jan. 16 will face fines.
The policy is “an act of justice for the vaccinated,” Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis said. https://t.co/P30U1VEWbb
How do you pronounce "Omicron" anyway? There is no single, agreed-on English pronunciation, experts say. https://t.co/5asGScAGtO https://t.co/5bUDgNznRt
How do you pronounce "Omicron" anyway? There is no single, agreed-on English pronunciation, experts say. https://t.co/PwypHPfQGC https://t.co/exm4AiNna3
How do you pronounce "Omicron" anyway? There is no single, agreed-on English pronunciation, experts say. https://t.co/uIYUXE5TZW https://t.co/2Oc93s4HSB

In 1911, someone checked out a copy of the book "New Chronicles of Rebecca" from a library in Boise, Idaho.
After 110 years, the volume mysteriously turned up this month at the city's main library in immaculate condition. https://t.co/vXUKRiD3CJ

In an attempt to curb overdose deaths, New York City will open the nation’s first authorized supervised injection sites for drug users. They will provide clean needles, administer naloxone to reverse overdoses and provide options for addiction treatment. https://t.co/JqkecqyNle

Julie Rikelman, now arguing against Mississippi's law, is the litigation director at the Center for Reproductive Rights. She argued successfully before the Supreme Court in 2020 against a Louisiana law, a significant victory for abortion rights supporters. https://t.co/GjGLibbN4r

Justice Sonia Sotomayor said that "15 justices over 30 years since Casey have reaffirmed that basic viability line," referring to Planned Parenthood vs. Casey which said that states could not impose an undue burden on the right to abortion. https://t.co/moRhmrL5dZ https://t.co/JWpl0A2qSV

Justice Sonia Sotomayor, a consistent supporter of abortion rights, grilled Mississippi's solicitor general, asking whether the institution of the Supreme Court would "survive the stench" of overturning Roe in what would appear to be a political act. https://t.co/sbHcIObnjQ

They struggled to get regular access to bathing. So the "shower bus" came to them.
The bus, based in New York, runs on free tokens and is about "giving people back some dignity," one organizer said. Swipe through to see how the program works. https://t.co/fAEXZMCFiU

Two cases of the Omicron variant were detected in the Netherlands more than a week ago, Dutch officials said. The announcement suggests that the variant had already reached Europe before countries rushed to impose travel limits. https://t.co/hUWAg02Yeu
Your reading list just got a longer — here are the 10 Best Books of 2021, selected by editors at The New York Times Book Review. https://t.co/wVWGzGDHm8 https://t.co/Rksggclq57

Barbados became a republic on Tuesday, cutting ties with Queen Elizabeth II and ending nearly 400 years of British rule. The island swore in its first president, Sandra Mason, at a ceremony attended by Prince Charles and Rihanna. https://t.co/7df327EP8u https://t.co/MkRlA2URLF

President Biden sought to reassure the U.S. about the Omicron variant of the coronavirus on Monday. It will likely be a week, possibly two, before experts know more about its transmissibility and severity. https://t.co/dB61ZtoqdP https://t.co/m8taZuByNP

Breaking News: Pfizer and BioNTech are expected to apply for approval of their coronavirus booster shot for 16- and 17-year-olds. If approved, the booster would be the first for anyone under 18 in the U.S. https://t.co/QZEBzWlrnQ

In 1787, Catherine the Great told a governor-general that among his most important duties "should be the introduction of inoculation against smallpox, which, as we know, causes great harm, especially among the ordinary people." https://t.co/w1I4BLxd4q
